questions.question_text: Which of the following protocols are classified as connectionless? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
TFTP (Trivial File Transfer Protocol): TFTP is a a simple form of the File Transfer Protocol (FTP). TFTP uses the User Datagram Protocol (UDP) and provides no security features. It has least amount of overhead, and as a result the fastest file transfer protocol.
SNMP uses UDP over IP. It Used to monitor and manage network devices
should it not be a and b ?

Answer should be C and F ?
There are a variety of supported connectionless protocols online, including HTTP (hypertext transfer), ICMP, IP, IPX, UDP, and TIPC.
strange question... the school wants to save on the cabling but replace the expensive switches?

comments.content: Yea, didn't you know? Switches are a buck ninety at the dollar store.

discussion.content: This question is awfully worded, i presumed instantly that the switches were the bottleneck and that they didn't support higher than 1Gb. Perhaps i didn't read the question correctly but CompTIA seriously need to sort out their wording.

comments.content: I agree completely, even though it might not make sense you know from reading it that it's link aggregation/port bonding, type of question.

choices.B: Replace the switches with ones that utilize port bonding and use the spare cables.
choices.C: Replace the switches with 10Gb switches and utilize the existing cabling.
choices.D: Plug in a second cable and set one port to TX and one port to RX.
choices.A: Plug in a second spare cable at each end to double the speed.

questions.question_text:
Users in a school lab are reporting slow connections to the servers and the Internet. Other users in the school have no issues. The lab has 25 computers and is connected with a single 1Gb Ethernet connection on Cat 5e wiring to an unmanaged switch. There are also three spare Cat 5e cable runs, which are not in use.
The school wants to double the connection speed between the lab and the servers without running new cables. Which of the following would be the BEST solution?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Its A because a certificate is something you have. Both a Pattern and Password is considered something you know. A Fingerprint is something you are.

questions.question_text: An administrator wants to implement an additional authentication factor to the remote SSH servers. Which of the following accomplishes this goal with the principle of `something you have`?
According to the OSI model, at which of the following layers is data encapsulated into a packet?

discussion.content:
Start at layer four and work down:
Some -- Segments
People -- Packets
Fear -- Frames
Birthdays -Bits

comments.content:
Some -- Segments --> Layer 4
People -- Packets --> Layer 3
Fear -- Frames --> Layer 2
Birthdays -Bits --> Layer 1
Birthdays

Just to be sure, that's set in the order of
Data Link
Network
Transport
Session
?
Cause I am so used to the top down model of Please Do Not Throw Sausage Pizza Away

This is the best one 
Mines is
Some 
People 
Fear
Bears
OMG I love you. Thanks for that info.

discussion.content:
Data at the TRANSPORT layer is a SEGMENT.
Data at the NETWORK layer is a PACKET. (I had to look this up, as I was confused)

Selected Answer: C
This is done in the transport layer, so Layer 4

Selected Answer: C
According to the OSI model, at which of the following layers is data encapsulated into a PACKET? (not frames)

from page 42 of the official CompTIA prayer guide and songbook. and here: 
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19455-01/806-0916/ipov-32/index.html#:~:text=As%20the%20packet%20travels%20through,process%20is%20called%20data%20encapsulation.

Transport Layer--Data Encapsulation Begins
When the data arrives at the transport layer, the protocols at the layer start the process of data encapsulation. The end result depends on whether TCP or UDP has handled the information.

The Networking layer is primarily concerned with logical addressing, route discovery and selection, connection services, etc. this layer adds more data to the packet.

The data link layer packages these encapsulated packets into Frames. 

IF the CompTIA book says it's layer 4, and you want to pass the test, choose layer 4.

comments.content: Ive lived in Brooklyn before... and I agree, dont send them.

discussion.content:
my pneumonic is 
Dont - Data (layers 5-7)
Send - Segment (layer 4)
People - Packet (Layer 3)
From - Frame (Layer 2)
Brooklyn - Bit (layer 1)

Transport Layer: Datagram (UDP) or Segment (TCP)
Network Layer: Packet (IP) 
Data Link Layer: Frame
Physical Layer: Bit

questions.question_text: A junior technician is setting up a voice control device so the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) will be able to control various things in the office. Of which of the following types of IoT technologies is this an example?

comments.content: control things in his own office not establishment. PAN is like the correct answer.

discussion.content: If he wants to control various things in the office, how is this PAN? PAN applies only to your personal workspace. I think the correct answer here is LAN
CONTROL various dev (UP TO 7 devices) in one room (up to 300ft) @PAN
PAN (Personal Area Network) and is mainly used for connecting peripherals, like bluetooth.
